content.text: consists of fully connected dense layers that transform input data from one dimension to another. It is called
because it contains an input layer, one or more hidden layers and an output layer. The purpose of an MLP is to model complex relationships between inputs and outputs.
: Each neuron or node in this layer corresponds to an input feature. For instance, if you have three input features the input layer will have three neurons.
: MLP can have any number of hidden layers with each layer containing any number of nodes. These layers process the information received from the input layer.
: The output layer generates the final prediction or result. If there are multiple outputs, the output layer will have a corresponding number of neurons.

Every connection in the diagram is a representation of the fully connected nature of an MLP. This means that every node in one layer connects to every node in the next layer. As the data moves through the network each layer transforms it until the final output is generated in the output layer.
Let's see working of the multi-layer perceptron. The key mechanisms such as forward propagation, loss function, backpropagation and optimization.
the data flows from the input layer to the output layer, passing through any hidden layers. Each neuron in the hidden layers processes the input as follows:
: The neuron computes the weighted sum of the inputs:

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: : The weighted sum z is passed through an activation function to introduce non-linearity. Common activation functions include:
Once the network generates an output the next step is to calculate the loss using a

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: . In supervised learning this compares the predicted output to the actual label.
For a classification problem the commonly used

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer
text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: The goal of training an MLP is to minimize the loss function by adjusting the network's weights and biases. This is achieved through

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: : The gradients of the loss function with respect to each weight and bias are calculated using the chain rule of calculus.
: The error is propagated back through the network, layer by layer.

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: : The network updates the weights and biases by moving in the opposite direction of the gradient to reduce the loss: w=w−η⋅∂L∂w
​​ is the gradient of the loss function with respect to the weight.
MLPs rely on optimization algorithms to iteratively refine the weights and biases during training. Popular optimization methods include:

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: : Updates the weights based on a single sample or a small batch of data: w=w−η⋅∂L∂w

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text: : An extension of SGD that incorporates momentum and adaptive learning rates for more efficient training:
​​ represents the gradient at time t
Now that we are done with the theory part of multi-layer perception, let's go ahead and implement code in python using the TensorFlow library.
In this section, we will guide through building a neural network using TensorFlow.
First we import necessary libraries such as

content.text: for visualizing the data. We also load the

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text:
import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from tensorflow.keras.models import Sequential
from tensorflow.keras.layers import Flatten, Dense

(x_train, y_train), (x_test, y_test) = tf.keras.datasets.mnist.load_data()
Next we normalize the image data by dividing by
(since pixel values range from 0 to 255) which helps in faster convergence during training.
To understand the data better we plot the first 100 training samples each representing a digit.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(10, 10)
k = 0
for i in range(10):
    for j in range(10):
        ax[i][j].imshow(x_train[k].reshape(28, 28), aspect='auto')
        k += 1
plt.show()
: Reshapes 2D input (28x28 pixels) into a 1D array of 784 elements.
: Fully connected layers with 256 and 128 neurons, both using the relu activation function.
: The final layer with 10 neurons representing the 10 classes of digits (0-9) with

attrs.class: text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer
text-muted-foreground underline underline-offset-[3px] hover:text-primary transition-colors cursor-pointer

content.text:
model = Sequential([
    Flatten(input_shape=(28, 28)),
    Dense(256, activation='sigmoid'),  
    Dense(128, activation='sigmoid'), 
    Dense(10, activation='softmax'),  
])
Once the model is defined we compile it by specifying:
: Sparse categorical cross entropy, which is suitable for multi-class classification.

We train the model on the training data using 10 epochs and a batch size of 2000. We also use 20% of the training data for validation to monitor the model’s performance on unseen data during training.

mod = model.fit(x_train, y_train, epochs=10, 
          batch_size=2000, 
          validation_split=0.2)
          
print(mod)
After training we evaluate the model on the test dataset to determine its performance.
We got the accuracy of our model 92% by using
8. Visualizing Training and Validation Loss VS Accuracy
The model is learning effectively on the training set, but the validation accuracy and loss levels off which might indicate that the model is starting to overfit.
: MLPs can be applied to a variety of problems, both classification and regression.
: Using activation functions MLPs can model complex, non-linear relationships in data.
: With the help of GPUs, MLPs can be trained quickly by taking advantage of parallel computing.
: MLPs can be slow to train especially on large datasets with many layers.
: Without proper regularization techniques they can overfit the training data, leading to poor generalization.
: They require properly normalized or scaled data for optimal performance.
In short Multilayer Perceptron has the ability to learn complex patterns from data makes it a valuable tool in machine learning.
